information:
As of mid-May 2025, New York Yankees player Aaron Judge's batting average was reported at various points between .402 and .423. On May 17, after a 2-for-4 game, his average reached .414, though a subsequent 0-for-5 game lowered it. By May 18, Judge had accumulated 15 home runs and 41 RBI for the season, leading the league in several offensive categories. An analysis by MLB.com noted that achieving a .414 batting average with over 15 home runs within a team's first 44 games is a rare historical feat, with parallels to seasons by Mickey Mantle in 1956 and Manny Ramirez in 2001.

According to a list of National League batting leaders published on May 18, 2025, Freddie Freeman of the Los Angeles Dodgers was leading with a .375 average. Other top hitters included Will Smith (Los Angeles Dodgers) at .336, Brendan Donovan (St. Louis Cardinals) at .330, and Manny Machado (San Diego Padres) at .323. In the American League, David Alonso of the New York Mets had a team-high batting average of .308 as of May 17. In Triple-A, Chicago Cubs prospect Matt Shaw was reported to be hitting .400 over his last eight games.

The last Major League Baseball player to finish a season with a batting average of .400 or higher was Ted Williams, who hit .406 in 1941. One analysis noted that modern players face challenges in reaching this mark, such as higher strikeout rates; early in the 2025 season, Aaron Judge had 31 strikeouts, whereas Williams had only 27 in his entire 1941 season. Another factor is Batting Average on Balls In Play (BABIP). The major league-wide BABIP in 2025 is .288, compared to .300 in 1930. In 2000, Ichiro Suzuki recorded a .387 batting average but was limited to 105 games due to an injury.

forecast.status_quo_outcome: No, a player will not have a .400 batting average on June 1, 2025. While Aaron Judge is currently near this mark, batting averages this high are extremely volatile and subject to regression to the mean. The historical difficulty and statistical pressures of maintaining such an average make it likely to drop below .400 over the next two weeks.
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: Aaron Judge's performance, while still excellent, regresses closer to his career norms over the last two weeks of May. A few games where he goes 1-for-4 or 0-for-3 are enough to pull his season average below the .400 threshold. Other league leaders do not experience a significant enough hot streak to reach this mark by June 1.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Aaron Judge continues his historically exceptional performance through the end of May. He avoids any multi-game slumps and continues to get hits at a high rate, allowing him to maintain a batting average at or above .400 when the MLB statistical leaders are recorded on June 1, 2025.
forecast.rationale: My forecast is primarily driven by the strong statistical principle of regression to the mean. While the research confirms Aaron Judge is having a remarkable season and is currently flirting with a .400 batting average in mid-May, maintaining such an extreme outlier performance is exceptionally difficult as the sample size of at-bats increases. The last player to finish a season hitting .400 was Ted Williams in 1941, which underscores the historic difficulty of this feat, even over a shorter period like the first two months of a season. The modern game, with higher strikeout rates and defensive shifts contributing to a lower league-wide Batting Average on Balls In Play (BABIP), presents additional structural headwinds. A single slump or even a series of average games over the next two weeks would be sufficient to pull Judge's average below .400. While Judge's current performance is the sole reason this probability isn't near zero, the forces of statistical likelihood and historical precedent strongly suggest a 'No' outcome. My forecast is not lower because Judge's current proximity to .400 makes the 'Yes' outcome a tangible possibility. A player is actively achieving the benchmark now, which cannot be dismissed. My forecast is not higher because two weeks of baseball provides ample opportunity for the near-inevitable regression to occur. I would raise my probability if Judge were to increase his average further in the coming week, creating a larger buffer. Conversely, I would lower it substantially after his first significant hitless streak or multi-game slump.
